summary: This is a letter from Ghislaine Maxwell's defense attorney Laura A. Menninger to Judge Loretta A. Preska regarding the unsealing process in the civil case Giuffre v. Maxwell. The letter requests a temporary stay of unsealing due to new information learned on August 7, 2020, that impacts both the civil and criminal cases, and proposes modifications to streamline the unsealing protocol.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in both the civil case (Giuffre v. Maxwell) and the criminal case (U.S. v. Maxwell). Her counsel is requesting a stay of the unsealing process due to new information affecting her rights.

persons.name: Laura A. Menninger
persons.context: Attorney from Haddon, Morgan and Foreman, P.C., representing Ghislaine Maxwell. She authored this letter to Judge Preska regarding the unsealing process and new information.

persons.name: Loretta A. Preska
persons.context: Judge presiding over the civil case Giuffre v. Maxwell. The letter is addressed to her regarding the unsealing order and protocol.

persons.name: Judge Nathan
persons.context: Judge presiding over the criminal case U.S. v. Maxwell. The letter references a protective order from that case and the need to seek modification from Judge Nathan.

persons.name: Sharon Churcher
persons.context: Mentioned in the context of a motion to quash a subpoena (Docket 215) that is proposed for unsealing review.

persons.name: Doe 1
persons.context: A non-party whose deposition is subject to a stay by the Second Circuit. The letter discusses notification rights and obtaining new contact information for Doe 1.

connections.description: Laura A. Menninger is defense counsel representing Ghislaine Maxwell in the civil case, as indicated by the letterhead and content.
Judge Nathan is presiding over the criminal case U.S. v. Maxwell, involving Ghislaine Maxwell as the defendant.
Judge Preska is presiding over the civil case Giuffre v. Maxwell, involving Ghislaine Maxwell as the defendant.

events.title: Discovery of New Information
events.description: Counsel for Ghislaine Maxwell learned of critical new information that impacts both the civil and criminal cases, implicating due process and constitutional rights.

events.title: Court's Unsealing Order
events.description: The Court issued an order (Doc. 1069) regarding the unsealing process, which this letter responds to.

events.title: Previous Unsealing Order
events.description: The Court issued an unsealing order that is under review by the Second Circuit.

locations: United States District Court Southern District of New York, 500 Pearl Street, New York, NY 10007
keyFacts: Ghislaine Maxwell's counsel learned of critical new information on August 7, 2020, that affects both the civil and criminal cases, but cannot disclose it due to a protective order in the criminal case.
Maxwell's attorney requests a temporary stay of the unsealing process for approximately three weeks to address the protective order and present the new information to the courts.
The parties agreed to notify all Non-Parties at once regarding unsealing to gauge objections, but significant effort is required to prepare individualized excerpts for each.
The letter proposes reviewing five specific decided motions for unsealing that do not quote from materials subject to the Second Circuit's stay.
Maxwell's counsel raises concerns about errors in previous unsealings and requests procedural changes to require proposed unredacted pleadings upfront.
